pages.title: About OpenData
pages.text: OpenData is a database of publicly available datasets of potential interest to the Niv/Daw labs. We are mostly cataloging datasets involving reinforcement learning & decision making experiment, though we also keep tabs on computational psychiatry experiments and some self-report questionnaires. To browse the current catalog, follow the links above or use the search bar at the top-right of this page.

pages.title: Contributing to OpenData
pages.text: Contributions to OpenData are welcome! All of the code is managed through the GitHub repository. How to submit a datasetThere are three main ways you can submit a dataset for entry to OpenData, which are described in turn below. Note that they are ranked in order of preference, from most preferred to least preferred, by the maintainers of Open Data :) 1. Submit a pull requestTo directly add a dataset yourself, you can open a pull request on Github. First you should fork the OpenData library via GitHub and make modifications on your fork. The OpenData database is written in markdown using a standardized, easy-to-copy template. Once your modification is complete, submit a pull request to merge your changes into the docs branch of OpenData. Pull requests will be reviewed by the maintainers. 2. Open an issueTo advertise a dataset for entry into the database, you can open a new issue via GitHub. Please provide a link to a repository for the data and, if available, a link to a corresponding manuscript describing the data. 3. Email the maintainersA third and final way to advertise a dataset for entry into the database is to email the maintainers directly (zorowitz@princeton.edu). Please provide a link to a repository for the data and, if available, a link to a corresponding manuscript describing the data.

posts.title: Albrecht et al. (2016)
posts.text: Data for a study in which N=75 participants (N=45 patients with schizophrenia, N=30 healthy controls) completed the Pavlovian go/no-go task.

posts.title: Bach (2015)
posts.text: Data for a study in in which a total of N=83 participants across four experiments (N=20, N=21, N=22, N=20) completed a novel approach/avoidance sequential decision making task. The state/trait anxiety inventory was collected for all participants.

posts.title: Bach et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data for a study in which N=781 young adults (aged 14-24) completed a risky foraging task.

posts.title: Ballard et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data for a study in which N=32 participants completed a target detection task involving configural learning.

posts.title: Bavard et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data for a study in which N=800 participants completed a novel range adaptation task.

posts.title: Bennett, Radulescu et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data for a study in which N=120 participants completed a novel compound generalization task with mood inductions and eye-tracking.

posts.title: Bertram et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data for a study in which N=281 participants across two experiments (N=162, N=119) in which participants estimated the probabilities of neutral compound events and rated their current mood.

posts.title: Cavanagh et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=46 depressed individuals completed the probabilistic selection task.

posts.title: Chambon et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=102 participants across four experiments (N=24, N=24, N=30, N=24) completed a series of 2-arm bandit tasks involving partial vs. complete feedback, free vs. fixed choice trials, and go vs. no-go responses.

posts.title: Collins (2018)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=49 participants completed a reinforcement learning task with working memory demands.

posts.title: Correa et al. (2018)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=32 participants completed a novel reversal learning task in which the visibility of reward was manipulated.

posts.title: Csifcsak et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=46 participants completed a modified pavlovian go/no-go task where the probability of outcomes was modified across blocks of the experiment.

posts.title: Csifcsak et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=103 participants completed a modified pavlovian go/no-go task where the probability of outcomes was modified across blocks of the experiment.

posts.title: Decker et al. (2016)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=80 participants (N=30 children, N=28 adolescents, N=22 adults) completed the two-step task.

posts.title: Dezfouli et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=101 participants (N=34 healthy controls, N=34 unipolar depressed patients, N=33 bipolar depressed patients) completed a 2-arm bandit task.

posts.title: Dorfman & Gershman (2019)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=454 participants completed the Pavlovian go/no-go task wherein outcome controllability was manipulated.

posts.title: Erev et al. (2017)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=686 participants completed a decisions from descriptions task involving 210 unique gamble types.

posts.title: Fan et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=984 participants across two experiments (N=531, N=556 before exclusions) completed a 2-arm bandit task with drifting rewards. Participants completed multiple self-report measures of anxiety.

posts.title: Fradkin et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=58 participants completed a multi-arm reversal learning task. The OCI was collected to measure compulsivity symptoms.

posts.title: Franklin & Frank (2020)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=482 participants across three experiments (N=198, N=153, N=151) completed a novel grid-world task in which participants had to learn the mapping between goal values and button-response mappings across multiple contexts.

posts.title: Frey et al. (2017)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=1507 participants completed 39 risk-taking measures (e.g. decisions from description, BART, CCT), with a subsample of 109 participants completing a retest session after 6 months).

posts.title: Gagne et al. (2020)
posts.text: The data from a study in which N=233 participants across two experiments (N=86, N=147) completed a probabilistic volatility task and a series of self-report psychiatric symptom measures.

posts.title: Gillan et al. (2016)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=1961 participants across two experiments (N=548, N=1413) completed the two-step task and multiple self-report psychiatric symptom questionnaires.

posts.title: Gillan et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=138 participants across two experiments (N=88, N=50) completed the two-step task while undergoing inhalation of hypercapnic gas.

posts.title: Glockner & Pachur (2012)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=66 participants completed a decisions from description paradigm twice, separated by 1 week.

posts.title: Hammond et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=125 participants across two experiments (N=76, N=49) completed a probabilistic volatility task and a series of self-report psychiatric symptom measures.

posts.title: Goris et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=161 participants completed a multi-arm risk sensitivity task and the autism quotient questionnaire.

posts.title: Heffner et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=1006 participants across four experiments complete an economic (ultimatum) game to investigate the influence of emotion prediction errors on social choice. Participants also completed multiple self-report measures.

posts.title: Hein et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=42 participants completed a probabilistic volatility task.

posts.title: Homan et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=77 participants (combat veterans) completed a threat discrimination and reversal task.

posts.title: Hunter et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=741 participants completed an economic game (patent race) involving planning and measures of anxiety.

posts.title: Jang et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from 287 participants on a task probing the link between reward prediction errors and memory.

posts.title: Jean-Richard-dit-Bressel (2021)
posts.text: Data from N=135 on a gamified instrumental contingency learning task involving avoidable punishments.

posts.title: Klein et al. (2017)
posts.text: The data from 75 participants in a 2-arm bandit task with novel choice contexts introduced throughout the task. Behavior on the task shows agents learn how good an option is relative to an option with which it had previously been paired.

posts.title: Konstantinidis et al. (2018)
posts.text: Data from N=202 participants on a simple risky bandit task, which examined how the magnitude of prospective outcomes impacted risk preferences.

posts.title: Lefebvre et al. (2017)
posts.text: The behavior from 85 participants who performed a simple 2-arm bandit task.

posts.title: McDonald et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from N=82 participants on a complex multiplayer “penalty shot” game.

posts.title: Millner et al. (2018)
posts.text: Data from 52 participants on a modified pavlovian go/no-go task task where participants were made to either prevent or escape from aversive stimuli. This task involves no reward.

posts.title: Mkrtchian et al. (2017)
posts.text: A total of N=101 healthy participants and individuals with mood and anxiety disorders completed the pavlovian go/no-go task task.

posts.title: Moran et al. (2019)
posts.text: Study of MB retrospective-inference, wherein MB system resolves uncertainty present at the time of choice thereby guiding an MF credit-assignment.

posts.title: Moutoussis et al. (2018)
posts.text: Data from 600+ young adults (aged 14-24) who completed the pavlovian go/no-go task task. Young people with higher IQ relied less on Pavlovian guidance. The degree of Pavlovian influence was not a highly stable trait and did not depend on age or mood. (Data from Neuroscience in Psychiatry Network.)

posts.title: Najar et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data from three experiments (N=24, N=44, N=302) investigating the computational mechanisms underlying adaptive imitation in human reinforcement learning.

posts.title: Niv et al. (2012)
posts.text: Data from 16 participants on a 2-arm bandit task measuring preferences between certain and risky reward options.

posts.title: Nussenbaum et al. (2020)
posts.text: Two-step task data in children, adolescents, and adults.

posts.title: Palminteri et al. (2016)
posts.text: A study of adolescents (N=26; 12–17 years) and adults (N=24; 18–32 years) in a 2-arm bandit task involving factual and counterfactual learning.

posts.title: Palminteri et al. (2017)
posts.text: Data from N=40 participants who completed a 2-arm bandit task with and without counterfactual feedback.

posts.title: Pederson et al. (2021)
posts.text: N=21 MDD patients and N=35 age-matched healthy controls in an approach-avoidance task.

posts.title: Peterson et al. (2021)
posts.text: The choices13k dataset contains human decision rates on 13,006 risky choice problems.

posts.title: Pool et al. (2021)
posts.text: Multi-lab investigation of habit formation and expression in an outcome devaluation task with overtraining. N=300 participants with multiple questionnaires collected (depression, compulsivity, impulsivity, stress).

posts.title: Potter et al. (2017)
posts.text: Two-step task data in children, adolescents, and adults.

posts.title: Raab & Hartley (2020)
posts.text: Data from 61 participants, consisting of 20 children (8–12 years old), 20 adolescents (13–17 years old), and 21 adults (18–25 years old) on the valenced Go/No-Go task.

posts.title: Radulescu et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data from 500+ participants on the Niv et al. (2012) risk sensitivity task, Holt & Laury gambles, and BIS/BAS questionnaire.

posts.title: Rahnev et al. (2020)
posts.text: The Confidence Database At the time of publication, the Confidence Database contained 145 datasets with data from more than 8,700 participants and almost 4 million trials.

posts.title: Reed et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data from 3 experiments on a 3-arm probabilistic reversal-learning paradigm. Includes questionnaires measuring paranoia and depression.

posts.title: Robinson et al. (2019)
posts.text: The authors studied the computational basis of learning under uncertainty in healthy individuals and individuals suffering from a mix of mood and anxiety disorders. Participants were asked to choose between four competing slot machines with fluctuating reward and punishment outcomes during safety and stress. Overall, the data suggest that anxious individuals are quicker to update their behaviour in response to negative outcomes (increased punishment learning rates).

posts.title: Rouhani et al. (2018)
posts.text: Data from several hundred participants on a task probing the link between reward prediction errors and memory.

posts.title: Rouhani & Niv (2021)
posts.text: Data from 500 participants on a task probing the link between reward prediction errors and memory.

posts.title: Rutledge et al. (2021)
posts.text: This resource consists of data from a risky decision and happiness task that was part of The Great Brain Experiment (GBE) smartphone app. Data were collected from 47,067 participants aged 18+ between March 8, 2013 and October 5, 2015. These anonymous unpaid participants completed the task a total of 91,058 times making approximately 2.7 million choices and 1.1 million happiness ratings in total. This resource represents at least 6,000 hours of task data. A subset of 1,858 participants also completed a depression questionnaire and answered five questions about their depression history.

posts.title: Safra et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from N=200 participants who took part in an experiment involving reward learning in contexts with different levels of social information (absent, partial and complete). Behavioral analyses revealed a specific detrimental effect of depressive symptoms (but not anxiety) on behavioral performance in the presence of social information, i.e. when participants were informed about the choices of another player.

posts.title: Shin & Niv (2021)
posts.text: Data from eight experiments testing latent cause inference in a social domain.

posts.title: Sugawara & Katahira (2021)
posts.text: Data from N=150 participants on a series of 2-arm bandit tasks involving different reward probabilities and feedback (factual, counterfactual).

posts.title: Tomov et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from several hundred participants (across multiple experiments) in a reinforcement learning task with multiple goals and slowly changing rewards.

posts.title: Turi et al. (2017)
posts.text: This dataset contains three repeated measures of a standard reward-based reinforcement-learning task from 29 healthy male individuals who participated in three experimental sessions exploring cognitive placebo effects on reward learning.

posts.title: van Baar et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from four experiments (N = 501) where in participants predicted other players’ decisions across four economic games, each with different social tensions (for example, Prisoner’s Dilemma and Stag Hunt).

posts.title: Waltmann et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from N=40 healthy subjects who completed a probabilistic reversal learning task (PRLT) twice.

posts.title: Warren et al. (2017)
posts.text: Data from 22 participants on the horizons task, which how individuals navigate the explore-exploit tradeoff. Participants were given atomoxetine, a norepinephrine transporter blocker. In line with predicitons, there was an effect of atomoxetine on random, but not directed exploration. However, contrary to expectations, atomoxetine reduced rather than increased random exploration.

posts.title: Wu et al. (2018)
posts.text: Study of human exploration in environments with spatially correlated patterns of rewards.

posts.title: Wulff et al. (2018)
posts.text: The aggregated data from 28 publications of experiments studying decisions from description and experience.

posts.title: Zaller et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from N=99 participants on a modified online version of the horizons task.

posts.title: Zhu et al. (2019)
posts.text: Study of the behavior of patients with focal lesions to either basal ganglia or orbitofrontal cortex in a multi-strategy competitive game known to engage these regions. They find that whereas OFC patients are significantly impaired, BG patients show intact learning in the economic game. By contrast, when information about the strategic context is absent, both cohorts are significantly impaired.

posts.title: Zorowitz et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=386 participants completed a 3-arm reversal learning task and multiple self-report symptom measures.
